Baker</origin>     <pubdate>2011</pubdate>     <title>Tillage Practices in the Conterminous United States, 1989-2004--Datasets Aggregated by Watershed; tillage_lu92e</title>     <geoform>tabular digital data</geoform>      <serinfo>      <sername>Data Series</sername>      <issue>Data Series 573</issue>     </serinfo>     <pubinfo>      <pubplace>Reston, VA</pubplace>      <publish>U.S. Geological Survey</publish>     </pubinfo>      <onlink>http://water.usgs.gov/lookup/getspatial?ds573_tillage_lu92e</onlink>     <lworkcit>      <citeinfo>       <origin>Nancy T. Baker</origin>       <pubdate>2011</pubdate>       <pubtime>Unknown</pubtime>       <title>Tillage Practice Data for the Conterminous U.S., 1989-2004--Datasets Aggregated by Watershed</title>       <serinfo>        <sername>Data Series</sername>        <issue>Data Series 573</issue>       </serinfo>       <pubinfo>        <pubplace>Reston, VA</pubplace>        <publish>U.S. Geological Survey</publish>       </pubinfo>       <onlink>http://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/ds573</onlink>      </citeinfo>     </lworkcit>    </citeinfo>   </citation>   <descript>    <abstract>This dataset is an aggregation of county-level tillage practices to the 8-digit hydrologic unit watershed. The original county-level data were collected by the Conservation Technology Information Center (CTIC) and is a proprietary dataset. The CTIC collects tillage data by conducting surveys about tillage systems for all counties in the United States. Watershed aggregations were done by overlying the 8-digit HUC polygons with a raster of county boundaries and a raster of the 1992 enhanced National Land Cover Data for land use 61, 62, 82, 83, and 84 (cultivated land) to derive a county/land-use area weighting factor. The weighting factor was then applied to the county-level tillage data for the counties within each 8-digit HUC and summed to yield the total acreage of each tillage type within each 8-digit HUC watershed. Tillage systems include three types of conservation tillage (no-till, ridge-till, and mulch-till), reduced tillage, and intensive tillage. Total planted acreage for each tillage practice for each crop grown is reported to the CTIC.The dataset includes total planted acreage by tillage type for selected crops (corn, cotton, grain sorghum, soybeans, fallow, forage, newly established permanent pasture, spring and fall seeded small grains, and "other" crops) for 1989-2004. The CTIC did not collect data nationwide for 1999, 2001, and 2003. In addition, data were not collected for all counties every year. Missing data are coded with -9999. The companion WBDHUC8 geospatial dataset is available online: http://water.usgs.gov/lookup/getspatial?wbdhuc8.xml .</abstract>    <purpose>These data were developed as an ancilliary dataset to provide explanatory variables for U.S. Geological Survey water-quality investigations. The data were derived for use in regional and national studies.</purpose>    <supplinf>The data in this dataset are contained in one dbase table. The table can be appended, via a relate table, to a geospatial coverage of the 8-digit hydrologic unit (HU) boundaries by the numeric 8-digit HU code (the numeric 8-digit code does not contain the leading zero for HUCs < 10000000. These data are intended to be used with a geospatial coverage of 8-digit HU boundaries (available online: http://water.usgs.gov/getspatial?wbdhuc8.xml ).. The methods used to aggregate county-level tillage to 8-digit watersheds are provided in the accompanying data-series report: "Tillage Practices in the Conterminous United States, 1989-2004--Datasets Aggregated by Watershed" (Baker, 2011). The original county-level data are proprietary through the CTIC. Those needing access to the original data should contact Conservation Technology Information Center, West Lafayette, Ind., Web: www.ctic.purdue.edu.</supplinf>   </descript>   <timeperd>    <timeinfo>     <sngdate>      <caldate>2011</caldate>     </sngdate>    </timeinfo>    <current>publication date</current>   </timeperd>   <status>    <progress>In work</progress>    <update>As needed</update>   </status>   <spdom>    <bounding>     <westbc>-127.886246</westbc>     <eastbc>-64.623167</eastbc>     <northbc>51.602543</northbc>     <southbc>22.885847</southbc>    </bounding>   </spdom>      <keywords>    <theme>     <themekt>None</themekt>     <themekey>Inlandwaters</themekey>      <themekey>tillage practice</themekey>     <themekey>crop residue management</themekey>     <themekey>planted acreage</themekey>    </theme>    <place>     <placekt>None</placekt>     <placekey>Conterminous U.S.</placekey>     <placekey>agricultural land</placekey>     <placekey>inland waters</placekey></place>    <temporal>     <tempkt>None</tempkt>     <tempkey>1989-2004</tempkey>    </temporal>   </keywords>    <accconst>None</accconst>   <useconst>This data set was derived from county-level data and should be used for regional and national studies. Disaggregating the data to sub-county level is not recommended.</useconst>    <ptcontac>    <cntinfo>     <cntperp>      <cntper>Nancy T. Watershed aggregations were done by overlying the 8-digit HU polygons with a raster of county boundaries and a raster of either the 1992e or 2001 National Land Cover Data for cultivated land to derive a county/land-cover area weighting factor. The weighting factor then was applied to the county0level tillage data for the counties within each 8-digit HU and summed to yield the total acreage of each tillage type within each 8-digit HU watershed.</procdesc>     <srcused>F:\ atsyn104\ illage\\gis\ illage_lu92e_old.dbf.xml</srcused>     <procdate>20100813</procdate>     <proctime>Unknown</proctime>    </procstep>            </lineage>
